alert.note: Alert for Robeson (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued August 31 at 11:37AM EDT until further notice by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Northeast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County. Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Dillon, Marion and Horry Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...North Carolina... Great Pee Dee River At Pee Dee affecting Florence and Marion Counties. Black Creek At Quinby affecting Darlington and Florence Counties. Black River At Kingstree affecting Williamsburg County. Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. For the Northeast Cape Fear River...including Burgaw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Great Pee Dee River...including Bennettsville 10sw, Pee Dee...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black Creek...including Black Creek Nr Hartsville, Quinby... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Black River...including Kingstree...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Lumber River near Lumberton. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Low land flooding will occur along the river. The flood waters may affect some residential property as water backs up into the drainage ditches in the city. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:20 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 12.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this afternoon and continue rising to a crest of 13.8 feet just after midnight tonight. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by late tonight.
